column36: He has a social media promotions business that he has taught his wife how to manage.

Every 2-3 months he and his family walks barefoot for govardhan yatra 21 km. He has tried waking up at 4 am but failed. He feels that new people, new environment and waking up may be challenging in he 1st 2 weeks but he will adjust. He said that he is coming here for seva as a sevak so he is willing for whatsoever the task is.

Initially he did a job in advertising when internet boomed he moved to the internet. In 2021 his business collapsed because his partnership broke and his partner took away the clients with good words. That was stressful but he pulled himself back up and continued. He has a social media promotions business.

He is 12th pass. His BCom degree is private which means he only went to give exams. He can stitch with a stiching machine. He has stiched boy's shorts. His mom has worked as a ladies tailor. He loves playing cricket. But now he doesn't play much as everyone is married and busy. He can speak, read and write in Hindi and English.
He lives with mother, wife and 1 year daughter. His father is dead. They are supportive as they have seen the changes SMK has brought in him. His wife is a professor in college
He has rented shops and houses

When he was in school there was an FIR against him because of boys fighting but they managed it  and reached a resolution. He has tickets of car overspeeding and traffic light that he will pay off this week.

He has done SMK 4 times to perfect his practice. First time he did not follow through with shambhavi mandala because he did not understand how breathing can change a human. Second time he learned he did the mandala in 2022-2023. Third and Fourth time he did IE so that he can get corrections in his practice. Like he learned that he does not have to hold his breath when he is in a posture in nadi vibhajan. At the end of Shambhavi he gets emotional because it feels very good. He holds Koombhaka for 20s and Shoonyaka for 10s.
When he learned Angamardana recently he lost 12 kg in 3 months because of that. 

In volunteering he has managed events like marriages in family

He was well prepared for the call and seemed like someone who has the necessary enthusiasm and commitment to go through SP. He and his wife hope to put their daughter in Samskriti after 8 years or so.
He recently paid off loans.

Between active and sedentary. He wakes up 6-7 am. Drops his wife to college. Starts his day with neem, turmeric and honey in warm water. Finishes angamardana and SMK and walks on the terrace. At noon he has satvik food cooked by his mom. This is the only meal he has. Then he works on his business through his phone. At night he drinks a glass of triphala and sleeps. That takes away his hunger. Seems like he is committed to losing weight.

column54:
I'm looking to join Sadhanapada because I feel there’s more to life than just chasing goals and achievements. I want to understand myself better and find a sense of calm and clarity that isn’t easily shaken by everyday problems. 
 
Through this program, I hope to learn practices that help me manage stress, handle life’s ups and downs with a steady mind, and become a more positive, balanced person. My goal is to find a deeper purpose and inner strength that will help me live life with a sense of peace and kindness, and to share that positivity with others.
column55:
I understand that Sadhanapada has a very strict daily routine, with almost no personal time, no days off, and strict rules to follow in the ashram. I see this as a way to push myself beyond my usual habits and comfort zone. Sticking to such a routine will help me develop discipline, focus, and strength, which are things I really want to build in myself. 
I know it might be tough at first to give up personal time and follow such a structured lifestyle, but I’m ready for it. I believe this setup will help me stay focused on my inner growth without getting distracted. I’m prepared to follow the program’s rules and routines because I trust that this experience will bring about the change I’m looking for.
column56: I understand that the program will be physically demanding with activities like walking long distances, sitting cross-legged for long periods, and even doing tasks like farming. While it might be challenging at first, I feel ready to take it on. I know that these physical activities are part of the experience, helping to build strength, endurance, and patience. Though it may be tough at times, I’m willing to push myself and adapt, as I believe these challenges will help me grow both physically and mentally. I see it as a chance to learn to handle discomfort and build resilience.
column57: I’m fully willing to be assigned to any type of volunteering activity, whether it’s physically demanding or office-based, for the entire program. I understand that each task, whether it involves hard physical work or something more administrative, has its own value and is an important part of the experience. I’m ready to give my best, no matter the type of work assigned, as I know that this variety of tasks will help me grow, build resilience, and learn new skills. I see this as a chance to be fully involved, learn from every experience, and contribute wherever I’m needed.
column58: I’m comfortable with the idea of sharing my space with other volunteers, including staying in a dormitory, using shared bathrooms, and working closely during volunteer activities. I believe that sharing these spaces will help me learn to adapt, become more patient, and build a sense of community. It’s a chance to connect with others on a similar journey, learn from them, and support each other. While it may require adjusting to a new level of simplicity, I see this as part of the growth process and am ready to embrace it as part of the experience.
column59: My family is supportive of my decision to stay at the Isha Yoga Center for the entire program. They understand that I’m seeking personal growth and inner transformation, and they believe that this experience will be beneficial for me. While they’ll miss having me around, they appreciate the purpose behind this journey and are encouraging me to fully commit to the program without distractions. Their support gives me confidence to dive into the experience wholeheartedly.
column60:
I have a few questions: 
What kind of support is available if I face physical or emotional challenges during the program? 
Are there any specific preparations I should make, such as physical fitness or dietary changes, before joining? 
How is personal progress or growth tracked throughout the program? 
Are there any resources or reading materials you recommend before the program begins to help align with its teachings?

column54:
I wish to go through Sadhanapada at this particular time because I’ve experienced profound personal transformation through my Inner Engineering program and the practice of Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya over the last seven months. Having overcome fears that previously disrupted my sleep and thoughts, I now feel a renewed sense of clarity and inner peace. 
 
At 25 years old, I see this as a pivotal moment in my life where I can build a strong foundation for my future. Through Sadhanapada, I hope to deepen my spiritual practice and integrate the lessons I've learned. I want to cultivate greater mindfulness and enhance my ability to stay grounded amidst life's challenges. 
 
Being part of a community of like-minded individuals will not only provide support and encouragement but also inspire me to stay committed to my journey. This age is an important time for personal and spiritual growth, and I want to make the most of it. 
 
Ultimately, I aim to explore new dimensions of my practice, strengthen my connection to myself, and develop a more profound sense of purpose and commitment in my daily life. Sadhanapada feels like the perfect opportunity to continue this positive momentum and grow even further on my spiritual path.
column55:
I recognize that following the strict daily schedule and having very little personal time will be a significant adjustment. However, I see this structure as essential for deepening my practice and fostering discipline. While it may feel intense at times, I believe that the focused environment will help me stay committed to my goals and enhance my spiritual growth Also now i have a work schedule of almost 12 hours a day so dedication and unwavering attitude will help me focus.But i will leave all my work and come to give my 100% on my sadhana. 
Although personal time may be limited, the experiences I gain through sadhana and community involvement will be enriching and fulfilling. Ultimately, I believe this structured approach will help me cultivate a deeper connection with myself and the practices I am committed to.
column56:
I feel ready to embrace the physical demands of the program. Over the past seven months, my daily practice of Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya has already helped me build a sense of discipline and inner strength. While walking long distances, sitting cross-legged for extended periods, and engaging in physically demanding activities like farming may be challenging, I see them as valuable opportunities to push my limits and grow both physically and mentally. 
 
I understand that these activities are an integral part of the Sadhanapada experience, designed not just to test the body but to cultivate endurance, presence, and mindfulness. I’m confident that with the right attitude and willingness to adapt, I’ll be able to meet these challenges and find joy in them as part of my spiritual journey.
column57:
I am fully willing to take on any kind of volunteering activity assigned to me, whether it is physically intense or office-based, for the full duration of the program. I understand that each task, no matter how challenging or routine, is an essential part of the overall Sadhanapada experience, contributing to my growth and the collective purpose of the program. 
 
I see these activities as opportunities to cultivate discipline, humility, and a sense of service. Whether working on the field or performing office duties, I am committed to approaching each task with dedication, mindfulness, and an open heart. I believe that engaging fully in any role assigned to me will help deepen my practice and allow me to contribute meaningfully to the community.
column58:
Having already lived away from home since the age of 19, and experienced sharing space with roommates during both your education and job, I don’t see communal living as a hindrance for me. In fact, those past experiences have likely strengthened my ability to adapt to new environments, work well with others, and maintain a sense of personal balance even in shared spaces. 
 
I’ve learned how to coexist respectfully with others, manage shared facilities, and create a comfortable living environment despite potential challenges. These experiences have prepared me to embrace the dormitory stay, shared bathrooms, and collaborative volunteering activities during Sadhanapada with ease and openness. I look forward to the sense of community that comes from living and working closely with others, knowing that it will further enrich my journey.
column59: My family is supportive of my decision to stay at the Isha Yoga Center for the full duration of the Sadhanapada program. They understand that this is a significant step in my personal and spiritual growth. Over the years, they have seen the positive changes in me through my practices and how my commitment to Inner Engineering and Shambhavi Mahamudra Kriya has brought more clarity, peace, and focus into my life.
column60: At this point, I don’t have any additional questions about the program. Everything was clearly explained during the webinar, and I feel well-informed and ready for the experience. If anything does come up later, I’m confident I’ll be able to seek guidance or clarification when needed.

I feel this is the right time for me to focus intensively towards on my spiritual growth, develop clarity and a sense of purpose through the program. Also, the chance to offer myself selflessly through 'seva' will help me understand myself more deeply and allow me to break inner limitations. This program will be a significant step toward my inner transformation and fulfilment.

column54:
Why Sadhanapada at this particular time?  
 
At this stage in my life, I’m looking for a profound inner transformation that goes beyond just career success or external accomplishments. Sadhanapada offers a unique opportunity for me to deeply reflect, build emotional stability, and establish a sense of balance that I feel has been missing. I want to cultivate a mind that’s clear and resilient, capable of handling both life’s highs and lows with equanimity. 
 
 
What way(s) are you hoping to grow through the program? 
 
I hope to deepen my spiritual experience and immersing myself in a consecrated space where I can focus on my inner development. I’m really looking forward  to volunteering as my previous experience as a Linga Sevak really brought a sense of fulfillment and purpose and deepened my ife experince. Sadhanapada would personally allows me to explore living an ascetic life and develop a stronger foundation in self-awareness to life's face challenges with grace and clarity.

column36:
• Has been following Sadhguru since 2018 on social media.
    • Attended IE online in December 2023 and was deeply touched by the program. The subject of responsibility really struck a cord with him and he now feels a mother to the world.
    • Would like to spend the most amount of time in the ashram, in a structured and systematized program without any distractions to learn new practices and deepen his Sadhana.
    • After dealing with the death of both his parents between 2018-2021 now his life is in good order so he feels it's the right time to attend SP because he can give himself fully to it.
    • He completed his bachelor degree, has been living alone for the past three months, he's economically independent and has a good stable job but still he says that his life feels empty.
    • He has a deep spiritual yearning and a strong desire to live intensely.
column54: Sadhguru once said that the system he is building will yield great human beings and even someone more capable than him might arise from this system. I really want to be part of this powerful system and I feel like sadhanapada is a great step towards this. I want to stretch myself to the maximum and beyond I want to be uncomfortable and challenge myself and go through that consciously and gracefully and I feel like this is the right time for me to join sadhanapada as when I reflect upon my life I can clearly see that it has been falling together to allow this for me, being alive during Sadhgurus era and everything that I went through throughout my life makes me confident that I am meant to be on this spiritual path and it is my time now to enhance it and take solid steps towards it. I hope that through the program I will be able to grow mentally and spiritually I hope and I'm actually confident that I will come out of this program a totally different being I will be more conscious, more inclusive, more confident and committed even more towards my spiritual growth and towards being a walking temple as Sadhguru wants us to be

column47: Linga Seva is a profound and immersive spiritual experience at Dhyanlinga. In it my day began at 3.30 am, ensuring that we were at Dhyanlinga by 4.30 am. The seva involved a variety of activities, from morning cleaning in and around Dhyanlinga to attending the Guru Pooja led by Swami.   Throughout the day, I participated in guiding visitors, helping maintain the silence within the Dhyanlinga, and offering seva at the offering counter. We were responsible for maintaining the silence of the space while supporting thousands of visitors in experiencing the transformative power of Dhyanlinga. The day concluded with cleaning the Dhyanlinga. Also at Sandhyakalas there was Nada aradhana in which I also got a chance to play music bowl.  This experience allowed me to transcend physical as well as mental limitations,  in the powerful presence of Dhyanlinga.
column54:
Namaskaram 🙏,  
Currently I am in the last year of Bachelors degree in Mechanical Engineering and by next year April -May,  i will complete my degree. So after this completion , I feel the most crucial thing which is needed to be happen is Sadhanapada , as sharings from Annas and Akkas in  Linga seva  gave me glimpse of what it means to be in ashram and in presence of Sadhguru. So the Only thing which I feel can really make me set right for anything and everything which can take place in this tenure of life and make best out of it is Sadhanapada . And also it can be a tool to deepen clarity.
column55: This year I got a chance to volunteer for linga seva and it was an most influential experience, the 10 days totally changed everything about me , I was with total new sense of life . So, when I was a part of linga seva, everyday  started at early morning 4.30 am in Dhyanlinga  and it lasted till 10.30 pm with meeting with Swami. So even though being new to such schedule, it was hard to notice how's days passed . Being with Annas and Akkas made feel every task simple. So similarly with grace of Sadhguru this Sadhanapada will happen with ease .
column56: Even it sounds hard , but I have applied for Sadhanapada to break all limitations so this things are must . And I believe this all activities will happen with ease with Sadhgurus grace.

Namaskaram 🙏   
Currently, my family has some concerns about me staying at the Isha Yoga Center for the full duration of Sadhanapada. Their hesitation comes from the significant changes they noticed in me after I returned from Linga Seva—my eating habits, daily routine, and behavior shifted so much that they fear I may not return to the same lifestyle or even come back home. I understand that these concerns arise from their love and care, and it’s natural for them to feel this way.   
 
However, after witnessing the positive transformation in me, both my parents and some of our neighbors were inspired to take the Inner Engineering program offline. I believe that as they deepen their own practices through Shambhavi Mahamudra, they will gradually understand the immense value of Sadhanapada. Following Sadhguru’s guidance, I have also made it a point to express more love and care towards my parents, which is already fostering greater understanding and harmony.   
 
I am confident that over time they will appreciate why this program is essential for me. And if not right away, I trust that when they see the deeper transformation in me after completing Sadhanapada, their perspective will naturally shift. My focus is to remain fully involved in the process and to keep nurturing our bond with love, allowing it to dissolve any lingering concerns.

family gets property rents and depends on it. Willing to support financially, he saved some money  in the last few months as well.

He learnt Surya Kriya and Angamardhana last month, he does alternate day each. He came for trial period in May, initial days he felt why he was here and what he was doing, slowly he got used to seva and ashram. He came again for 15days during Navrati he left on Oct17th, His experience of sadhana is different in SuryaKund, he felt he was more flexible there, he was in farm and he enjoyed that activity too. He could not visit Yogeshwara linga as much as other temples, this time when he came to ashram he went to Devi first when they gave initial day off.

He was smiling throughout, happy, spoke everything openly, did not try to hold back on any information. he was same speaking about ashram, volunteering, Navratri time being here. Felt very calm and sat in ardhasiddha asana , came presentable. Travelled so many places - Gujarat, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Ladhakh, Ujjain, 12 jyothirlinga, and many more in the last few years after corona either solo or with friends. He went to Gym for 14months and when he started Shambhavi, his body was not flexible so he stopped gym. During covid when he had to stop his coaching in bengaluru mid way and come back home (hyderabad) as his mother was worried. He was in a low state as he had to drop out of college for cricket and drop out of cricket for family, at that time he used to watch TV, sleep, and play online games, it was very stressful for 4-5months,. then gym helped his alot to get him out of that situation.
None

Wakeup at 6am, shambhavi and HY, has peanuts and dry fruits, Devi songs for half an hour, 1-2hours sleep, brunch, goes to collect rents, then goes out with friends, eats dinner and sleeps. weekly twice he goes out with friends till late night and sleep around 1am. During his cricket training he used to run for 1hour continuously and not jog in between in 6months. He stopped non-veg in 2023. Eats Rice, sambar, dal, curry millet in brunch and dinner  After seeing yellow cycles in Ashram, he's planning to buy a cycle and to strengthen his body. Since he doesn't have much work to do he uses phone for 6hours in a day, didn't find any difficulty in not using phone during volunteering.

column36: Father owns a farming business. He is helping his father in farming. It is a family business, so he will take a break and come here. Father is able to manage without him, has another brother who can help father.
He has studied in hostel, so happy with the stay arrangement. Expressed interest in farming seva. Although happy to do whatever he gets. Willing to do anything and is not fussy about any aspect.

Since his schooling, he helped his father in farming. Completed studies and worked as an Electrical helper and then went to work in hospitality. Recently last year decided to join father again in farming.
Completed his12th std and then decided to go for Diploma in Electrician. No red flags.

Father is educated, mother is not. One elder brother and one younger sister. None of them are Isha meditator. He explained his parents what he is doing and they are happy to support. Happy for us to call them.

Father owns the farming business. He helps him in farming. He is not getting any salary but father supports his expenses. Suggested that they have enough savings and father will be happy to support him.
None

He has only done IE. No volunteering experience in Isha or otherwise. He has been to ashram to attend Guru Purnima program so know about Bhiksha hall and ashram in general. Mentioned that he has never seen such people outside who are so involved in the activity and want to help others.

Initially became nervous but then settled down. Speaking in English was also a bit of struggle. Completed full mandala and still practices twice a day. Needs minor practice corrections. I have given him the Hyderabad LC number. He suggested that the LCs are more than 100km from him, so he will attend monthly satsang online. Requested him to call us back after this is done. Came across as very innocent, simple, farmer boy. Wants to kick start his youth with spirituality. Suggested that before IE, his goal was materialistic oriented, now he is filled with compassion and wants to help people. Sadhguru's saying that one should not get entangled with life, struck him. He wants clarity and balance so that he can dissolve his 'I' and work in involvement with getting entangled. Seemed sincere and genuine. Answered respectfully. Willingness is there, intent is there but no vol experience so Selected with TP.
No loans

He wakes up around 7am, does Upa Yoga and Shambhavi, has his breakfast and goes to farm. They have Paddy and Cotton farm. He does seeding, sowing, fertilizing and harvesting. Family business so his father and him work together. Comes home by 5pm. Does Shambhavi again and then eats dinner before 7pm. Sleeps around 10-10:30pm. When he does not go to farm he sits with nature idle. He is in a village far away from the city so loves to spend time in nature. Naturally walks a lot as well.

column36:
✔ She was always focused on her career to do things but now she wants to be focused to be. As she said, these 7 months will give her the possibility to be a ‘human being’. After breaking up her long term relationship she had a question “who am I and what is my purpose in life?”, she realized that she doesn’t have any attachments and commitments so now it's a good time for SP. Also after her mother passed away it was a reminder for her to do something worthwhile in her life. She watched all the videos about Sadhanapada. She’s seeking intensity, clarity, and balance.

column47: Currently on Isha yoga center LA phone team
column54: For much of my life I have gone through the steps of "having, doing and being". After reading "Karma" I have realized my path should be "being, doing, and having." My life to this point has been about achievements and goals - medical school, residency, fellowship, board certification, professorship, being in a "perfect" relationship, climbing mountains, performing in dance teams. Now that my long term relationship has ended I have started to question who and what I am in life. If I am no longer a future wife of my former partner then I started to question the other labels I have created - hiker, dancer, doctor, professor, daughter, sister. Realizing they will all too come to an end at some point in time, it leaves me with more questions than answers as to why I am here and what this life is truly about. I would like to start from the beginning and focus on "being" human. If I understand myself better and have a sense of fulfillment within, then my "doing" (interaction) with others is a natural byproduct and then the "having" is a natural second byproduct of that. If those "labels" I have created for myself (dancer, hiker, doctor, professor, etc) come to an end, then I will still be a whole person because I have focused on the "being" aspect. Sadhanapada would give me the dedicated and focused time to go inward and focus on "being", leaving the labels behind and blossoming from within. With this period of introspection I could then return to my medical school, hospital, friends/family with more joy, peace and creativity. It would in turn affect those around me - students, patients, friends/family. Life should be an expression of your happiness and not a pursuit of it. Sadhanapada will be the first step in finding my happiness within.
column55: I look forward to the strict daily schedule within the ashram. Having no "days off" means you are continually striving for something greater that will transform you.
